text:
I think it's a good idea if you want to expand your market. However, keep in mind that the messaging for nonprofits is often Very Different than the ones for-profits use, and they will often bristle at the suggestion that you'd be using similar tactics... so it's important to have separate messaging as well rather than just a different rate

(source: work for a company that makes nonprofit tech and am part of a ton of nonprofit facebook groups)

also to <@UUXMCJQ15>'s point - it really depends on the kind of nonprofits you're going after. agreed that if you want to hit the big guys, they don't need a discounted rate, but there are tons of grassroots groups that need the help a lot more and who definitely can't afford much... just depends on how charitable you want to be :stuck_out_tongue:

text: I found an answer on another forum just in case anyone is interested - a non-profit could provide a contractor with a tax receipt for their “donated time” (aka the discount) to help at the end of the year

text: Oh yeah. Whenever you give a discounted rate, you can bill for the full amount and include the discount in the invoice.

elements.text: Oh yeah. Whenever you give a discounted rate, you can bill for the full amount and include the discount in the invoice.
